parent.body:
Life isn't benevolent and it isn't malevolent. You get dropped into a maelstrom of opportunities and challenges and you try to make the best of it.

Yeah, you can do everything right and still fail. But your odds of happiness do vastly improve when you do your best.

post.body:
There are two main ways people try to get around this fact. One group of people says that you create your own luck, your own destiny, etc., you choose to be happy or unhappy, everything is by perseverance, genes don't mean anything, etc. Basically they insist that the world is fair and the choice is yours. The other group acknowledges that we are unfairly divided by biology, external circumstances, etc. but they somehow manage to glorify it, saying that is how it *should* be. The first position is a lie. The second one is evil.

This is obviously mental gymnastics to stop us from admitting the truth. Yes, people have almost no say in their lives and nearly everything is determined for them, and no, it's not a good thing. And no, there's nothing we can do about it. It's the truth, and we're not getting anywhere by trying to get around it. You get what you are handed, and that's the end of it. It's the red/black pill.

> It doesn’t seem like you’ve tried enough.

parent.body:
Sure, no amount of debate over nature versus nurture is going to help you, or really anyone. They're just words.

There's no way to know whether you're "broken for life" until after you're dead.

Your best chance would be to identify what needs you have that aren't getting met and strategize about how to get them met.

parent.body:
@CrystalVulpine
You didn’t respond to my question and it’s buried so I’m posting it here.

Have you ever experienced agonizing pain? 

I’m talking about the kind of pain that has you writhing on the floor for hours and begging mercy from spiritual figures you aren’t even sure you believe in.

While I wouldn’t wish that on anyone, it’s the kind of thing that changes how you see the world. 

It makes you appreciate the everyday things you take for granted. Like living without terrible pain. Having energy and moving with ease. It makes you feel grateful for feeling “normal” again because it feels so much better than being in pain.

It doesn’t matter what you’ve decided your perspective has to be “biologically”. There are always experiences that can change you.

All it takes is something much worse happening for you to see how good you had it.

parent.body:
It's probably not useful for you to try to predict the future.

Here's the thing: lots of people with no particular talents or charisma live happy lives. They're humble lives, but they're happy. You know, they raise some kids and go fishing a lot with a six pack of beer.

Maybe your real problem is a disconnect between your expectations for your life and achievable outcomes for your life.

> This doesn’t matter even if you are though. Usually people don’t choose to be in pain.

I'd pass out or die from shock or if it went on longer than like 10 minutes probably kill myself, even if it were only like 1/10th the intensity. I just can't handle it, because I'm a worthless sack of shit who can't do anything right.

> Maybe this is something you can be grateful for though - being able to live pain-free.

I can't, again because I just can't change my thinking like that. I am a born pessimist and selfish bag of horse shit. I used to be a little bit more grateful but not a lot, and then after puberty hit I just can't tolerate even the slightest discomfort anymore, and my empathy is limited. I hate it and I would go back if I could, but my mind is locked this way and no matter how hard I've fought it I just fall back on it because it's my nature. Even if I'm determined to change, in the moment I just can't and always do the same thing. It's nature.

"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

parent.body:
You can't just "change them at will," but you can adjust your expectations.

Like, you know, I had a friend whose lifelong dream was to be a famous director like Spielberg or Cameron or Fincher.

He couldn't cut it. He didn't have the chops. He failed. And he was depressed bordering on suicidal.

But eventually he found that being a sound editor for films *was* something he had the chops for, and... it pays well and he has a nice life.

body: The reason I know I can't ever fix it is because it's been shown to be rooted in brain structure. I am pessimistic, selfish, can't tolerate the slightest discomfort, unproductive, unintelligent, uncreative, untalented, constantly depressed and angry, forgetful, etc. and that's all down to biology just as much as height and speed are. No matter how hard I try to rebel against this I always fall back and end up doing the same things anyway and nothing ever changes. All resistance is futile, nurture never overcomes nature. And it wasn't quite as bad before I hit puberty and my brain was more malleable, so that's another reason I know it's probably uncontrollable. And I bet I'll have to be this way for the rest of my life, just a miserable worthless piece of flesh who does nothing but take up space and be a nuisance to the people who are actually worth something.

body:
Or just become more used to it.

I don't think you understand just how bad I am. It can't be only depression, because that is *caused* by many of these other things. I'm sick of not being able to do anything or even take anything slightly hard. Even in this thread alone people have done the impossible (for me). And a few people I've encountered in the past year can do literally anything, without a single fault, with very little experience, perfectly, and with little thought or effort, and they know literally every single tiny detail about everything in the universe, almost automatically. And a few of them have almost everything else going for them too, even the most minor details of life. It drives me insane and makes me wonder if some of them might even be fake people sent to test how we react to them or something.

And on top of that I'm selfish and pessimistic and unthankful and uncaring and a miserable wretch who just takes up space. Can't change that either, you can see I hate it, being so rotten like this, but when it comes to acting differently I simply can't do it. It's in my nature to be this way, that I can tell. Can't even change my thinking, it's how I'm wired.

I suspect you really have *one* problem - depression.

Is that "down to biology"? Sort of. But it's not some permanent facet of your brain structure. In fact, it's extremely common for someone who's suicidally depressed at 20 to be just fine at 30.

And in fact I'm in that category.

post.body:
There are two main ways people try to get around this fact. One group of people says that you create your own luck, your own destiny, etc., you choose to be happy or unhappy, everything is by perseverance, genes don't mean anything, etc. Basically they insist that the world is fair and the choice is yours. The other group acknowledges that we are unfairly divided by biology, external circumstances, etc. but they somehow manage to glorify it, saying that is how it *should* be. The first position is a lie. The second one is evil.

This is obviously mental gymnastics to stop us from admitting the truth. Yes, people have almost no say in their lives and nearly everything is determined for them, and no, it's not a good thing. And no, there's nothing we can do about it. It's the truth, and we're not getting anywhere by trying to get around it. You get what you are handed, and that's the end of it. It's the red/black pill.

Edit: seeing as my post was yanked to +IncelTears, no this isn't an incel problem. I mean incel problems are one thing this encompasses, but I'm not an incel nor was it the point of this post.

post.body:
Conservative Christianity has done nothing at all in conserving anything from the Early Church. In fact, these "conservative" Christians have adopted very modern, heretical ideas.

1. Destructive End times
2. Eternal Torment in Hell
3. Just Wars for country, violence can save for the greater good
4. God Killed Jesus for you (Penal Substitution Theory)
5. Pledging Allegiance to your empire

In contrast true conservative Christianity is

1. Revelation has already happened,   Christians understood that Jesus achieved total victory on the cross and so the world would continue to get better as his Kingdom expanded and overtook the earth

2. The Church has always had three different views on hell: Universal Reconciliation, Annihilationism/Conditional Immortality, and Eternal Conscious Torment. We know that there were six theological schools operating in the first five or six centuries of Christianity in the cities of Alexandria, Antioch, Caesarea, Edessa, Ephesus, and Rome. Four of these schools taught Universal Reconciliation, one school taught Annilhilationism, and one taught Eternal Torment. So for around 500 years after the time of Christ, the majority view was Universal Reconciliation.   The one school that taught Eternal Torment was in Rome so that belief rose to dominance once the Emperor adopted the religion.  The Catholic Church used the fear of hell to motivate its parishioners for 1,500 years and so it is no wonder it is the major view today.

3. Christ was Pacifist and taught non-violence and commanded that you love your enemies.  In the early Church, Those who were in the military were not allowed to be baptized unless they abandoned their positions. It wasn’t even permitted for a Christian to wear any jewelry that had symbols of weapons on them.

4. This Idea was popularized by the Reformation especially John Calvin.  The Gospel according to Jesus was that the Kingdom of God had arrived. Jesus talked about this more than anything else, and the Kingdom is always how the Gospel is described in Scripture.

5. Jesus taught to be a citizen of the Kingdom of God.  Empires of the world are anything but.

Our "conservative" Christian friends have been led astray, and I hope that in time, they will come to correct their path.

post.body:
There are two main ways people try to get around this fact. One group of people says that you create your own luck, your own destiny, etc., you choose to be happy or unhappy, everything is by perseverance, genes don't mean anything, etc. Basically they insist that the world is fair and the choice is yours. The other group acknowledges that we are unfairly divided by biology, external circumstances, etc. but they somehow manage to glorify it, saying that is how it *should* be.
